I partly agree with this, I do think that using cylindrical coordinates will improve the model, but the problem is not quite that symmetric to remove the azimuth. Particularly if you look at the bottom of a coke bottle, the bottom does have an azimuthal symetry which depends on the azimuth angle, the bottom is not completely round. This is important as the point of failure at the bottom of the bottle, 1:48 on original video, is at angle which corresponds to the part between two indentations.

When one is  scanning hundreds of resumes, it is nice to be able to throw out as many as possible as soon as possible. If someone's online profile is tainted with slander...Oh well...the loser needs to read up on Google Page Rank and spend hundreds of hours cleaning up the mess that one little brat created in half an hour.Out goes the loser's resume and on to someone who has a clean online profile.
The potential to create eye for an eye is HUGE!Then everyone will be fighting rather than working.

GoAnimate has high traffic because kids nowadays  are often playing video games and creating cartoons, instead of studying.  It is a perfect site to boost the Google Page Rank of any slander you wish to circulate about someone you hate.  GoAnimate doesn't police the content either.  Want to circulate  a video suggesting that your rival is gay and not worth hiring?  GoAnimate and Google can help circulate that video for you and PRESTO!  No jobs for losers!  Let them die homeless on the streets!

HOPEFULLY,  someday, the workers at Google and YouTube will come to grips with the fact that their search engine and video site , if left the way they are, will eventually become a replacement for the justice department. 

Middle school kids can now blacklist kids or even teachers that they don't like using Google.

How? Go it a site like GoAnimate, publish an embarrassing video about someone you hate, share it with hundreds of people and PRESTO! You've blacklisted your rival. No job for putz!

Great video, but there's a small error in the numerics of the blast simulations. The problem is axysymmetric, but the Laplace operator in the wave equation should be the operator in cylindrical coordinates (with the term in phi cancelling out because the problem is axysymmetric), which has one additional term than the two dimensional Laplace equation in cartesian coordinates. This term could easily be added to Mr. Dupont's simulations and would probably make the results even better.
